references.bibtex:
@article{10.1145/226643.226644,
author = {Selman, Bart and Kautz, Henry},
title = {Knowledge compilation and theory approximation},
year = {1996},
issue_date = {March 1996},
publisher = {Association for Computing Machinery},
address = {New York, NY, USA},
volume = {43},
number = {2},
issn = {0004-5411},
url = {https://doi.org/10.1145/226643.226644},
doi = {10.1145/226643.226644},
abstract = {Computational efficiency is a central concern in the design of knowledge representation systems. In order to obtain efficient systems, it has been suggested that one should limit the form of the statements in the knowledge base or use an incomplete inference mechanism. The former approach is often too restrictive for practical applications, whereas the latter leads to uncertainty about exactly what can and cannot be inferred from the knowledge base. We present a third alternative, in which knowledge given in a general representation language is translated (compiled) into a tractable formallowing for efficient subsequent query answering.We show how propositional logical theories can be compiled into Horn theories that approximate the original information. The approximations bound the original theory from below and above in terms of logical strength. The procedures are extended to other tractable languages (for example, binary clauses) and to the first-order case. Finally, we demonstrate the generality of our approach by compiling concept descriptions in a general frame-based language into a tractable form.},
journal = {J. ACM},
month = mar,
pages = {193224},
numpages = {32},
keywords = {Horn clauses, efficient reasoning methods, knowledge compilation, knowledge-base optimization, query evaluation, theory approximation}
}

references.bibtex:
@inproceedings{10.5555/2283516.2283536,
author = {Darwiche, Adnan},
title = {SDD: a new canonical representation of propositional knowledge bases},
year = {2011},
isbn = {9781577355144},
publisher = {AAAI Press},
abstract = {We identify a new representation of propositional knowledge bases, the Sentential Decision Diagram (SDD), which is interesting for a number of reasons. First, it is canonical in the presence of additional properties that resemble reduction rules of OBDDs. Second, SDDs can be combined using any Boolean operator in polytime. Third, CNFs with n variables and treewidth w have canonical SDDs of size O(n2w), which is tighter than the bound on OBDDs based on pathwidth. Finally, every OBDD is an SDD. Hence, working with the latter does not preclude the former.},
booktitle = {Proceedings of the Twenty-Second International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence - Volume Two},
pages = {819826},
numpages = {8},
location = {Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain},
series = {IJCAI'11}
}
references.title: A. Darwiche, "SDD: a new canonical representation of propositional knowledge bases," Proceedings of the Twenty-Second International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence - Volume Two, pp. 819826, 2011.

references.bibtex: @article{Van den Broeck_Darwiche_2015, title={On the Role of Canonicity in Knowledge Compilation}, volume={29}, url={https://ojs.aaai.org/index.php/AAAI/article/view/9423}, DOI={10.1609/aaai.v29i1.9423}, abstractNote={ <p> Knowledge compilation is a powerful reasoning paradigm with many applications across AI and computer science more broadly. We consider the problem of bottom-up compilation of knowledge bases, which is usually predicated on the existence of a polytime function for combining compilations using Boolean operators (usually called an Apply function). While such a polytime Apply function is known to exist for certain languages (e.g., OBDDs) and not exist for others (e.g., DNNFs), its existence for certain languages remains unknown. Among the latter is the recently introduced language of Sentential Decision Diagrams (SDDs): while a polytime Apply function exists for SDDs, it was unknown whether such a function exists for the important subset of compressed SDDs which are canonical. We resolve this open question in this paper and consider some of its theoretical and practical implications. Some of the findings we report question the common wisdom on the relationship between bottom-up compilation, language canonicity and the complexity of the Apply function. </p> }, number={1}, journal={Proceedings of the AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence}, author={Van den Broeck, Guy and Darwiche, Adnan}, year={2015}, month={Feb.} }
references.title: G. Van den Broeck and A. Darwiche, "On the Role of Canonicity in Knowledge Compilation," Proceedings of the AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence, vol. 29, 2015.

references.bibtex: @article{Bova_2016, title={SDDs Are Exponentially More Succinct than OBDDs}, volume={30}, url={https://ojs.aaai.org/index.php/AAAI/article/view/10107}, DOI={10.1609/aaai.v30i1.10107}, abstractNote={ <p> Introduced by Darwiche (2011), sentential decision diagrams (SDDs) are essentially as tractable as ordered binary decision diagrams (OBDDs), but tend to be more succinct in practice. This makes SDDs a prominent representation language, with many applications in artificial intelligence and knowledge compilation. We prove that SDDs are more succinct than OBDDs also in theory, by constructing a family of boolean functions where each member has polynomial SDD size but exponential OBDD size. This exponential separation improves a quasipolynomial separation recently established by Razgon (2014), and settles an open problem in knowledge compilation (Darwiche, 2011). </p> }, number={1}, journal={Proceedings of the AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence}, author={Bova, Simone}, year={2016}, month={Feb.} }
references.title: S. Bova, "SDDs Are Exponentially More Succinct than OBDDs," Proceedings of the AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence, vol. 30, 2016.

matrix.description: The existence of polysize knowledge compilation functions for clausal entailment implies the collapse of the polynomial hierarchy. Also, note that $d$-$DNNF$ supports a polynomial-time clausal entailment test. If $CNF$ could be polynomial-time transformed to $d$-$DNNF$, then we could perform a clausal entailment test with any $CNF$ sentence by transforming it to a $d$-$DNNF$ clause.

d-SDNNFd-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNFd-SDNNF in polynomial time, then CNFd-DNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts CNFd-DNNF being no-poly-unknown-quasi \citet{Cadoli_1997,Selman_1996,Darwiche_2002}.
PICNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If CNFDNF in quasipolynomial time, then PIDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts PIDNF being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

The existence of polysize knowledge compilation functions for clausal entailment implies the collapse of the polynomial hierarchy. Also, note that $DNNF$ supports a polynomial-time clausal entailment test. If $CNF$ could be polynomial-time transformed to $DNNF$, then we could perform a clausal entailment test with any $CNF$ sentence by transforming it to a $DNNF$ clause.

PICNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If CNFFBDD in quasipolynomial time, then PIFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts PIFBDD being no-quasi \citet{Wegener_1987,Darwiche_2002}.
IPDNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If CNFIP in quasipolynomial time, then CNFDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts CNFDNF being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.
MODSDNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If CNFMODS in quasipolynomial time, then CNFDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts CNFDNF being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

nFBDDDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNFnFBDD in polynomial time, then CNFDNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts CNFDNNF being no-poly-unknown-quasi \citet{Selman_1996,Cadoli_1997,Darwiche_2002}.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $CNF$ is a subset of $NNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.

nOBDDDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNFnOBDD in polynomial time, then CNFDNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts CNFDNNF being no-poly-unknown-quasi \citet{Selman_1996,Cadoli_1997,Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD$_<$FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If CNFOBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then CNFFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts CNFFBDD being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.
It is well-known that some $CNF$ formulas (i.e. $\neg PARITY_n=\neg\bigoplus_{i=1}^n x_i$) have exponentially many prime implicants.

SDDd-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. If CNFSDD in polynomial time, then CNFd-DNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts CNFd-DNNF being no-poly-unknown-quasi \citet{Cadoli_1997,Selman_1996,Darwiche_2002}.

SDNNFDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNFSDNNF in polynomial time, then CNFDNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts CNFDNNF being no-poly-unknown-quasi \citet{Selman_1996,Cadoli_1997,Darwiche_2002}.

uFBDDd-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNFuFBDD in polynomial time, then CNFd-DNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts CNFd-DNNF being no-poly-unknown-quasi \citet{Cadoli_1997,Selman_1996,Darwiche_2002}.

uOBDDd-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If CNFuOBDD in polynomial time, then CNFd-DNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts CNFd-DNNF being no-poly-unknown-quasi \citet{Cadoli_1997,Selman_1996,Darwiche_2002}.
OBDDFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If CNFOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then CNFFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts CNFFBDD being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

dec-DNNFFBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Beame_2013}. If CNFdec-DNNF in quasipolynomial time, then CNFFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts CNFFBDD being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

dec-SDNNFFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If CNFdec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then CNFFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts CNFFBDD being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD$_<$d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If d-DNNFCNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts OBDD$_<$CNF being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

d-SDNNFuOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. If d-DNNFd-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNFuOBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFuOBDD being no-quasi \citet{Amarilli_2018}.

OBDD$_<$d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If d-DNNFDNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts OBDD$_<$DNF being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, d-DNNF is a subset of DNNF, so a polynomial transformation is trivial.

$d$-$DNNF$s can polynomially represent the disjunction of two functions with conflicting variable orders, which forces $FBDD$s to grow exponentially to track the state of both orders within a single "read-once" path.
IPDNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If d-DNNFIP in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNFDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFDNF being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.
The function $ANY_n=\bigvee_{i=1}^nx_i$ can be represented in $O(n)$ as a $d-DNNF$ formula but has $2^n-1$ models.

noPolyDescription.description: dec-SDNNFd-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNFnFBDD in polynomial time, then dec-SDNNFnFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts dec-SDNNFnFBDD being no-poly-quasi \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bova_2016}.

quasiDescription.description: d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Bova_2016}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from d-DNNF to nFBDD.

matrix.description:
First, we show no polynomial transformation exists.
dec-SDNNFd-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNFnFBDD in polynomial time, then dec-SDNNFnFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts dec-SDNNFnFBDD being no-poly-quasi \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bova_2016}.

Now, we show a quasipolynomial transformation exists.
d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Bova_2016}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from d-DNNF to nFBDD.
d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from d-DNNF to NNF.

FBDDd-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. nOBDDSDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNFnOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then FBDDSDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts FBDDSDNNF being no-quasi \citet{Capelli_2016,Pipatsrisawat_2010}.

OBDD$_<$FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If d-DNNFOBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNFFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFFBDD being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2000}.
PICNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If d-DNNFPI in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNFCNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFCNF being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

SDNNFnOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. If d-DNNFSDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNFnOBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFnOBDD being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

noPolyDescription.description: uFBDDnFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNFuFBDD in polynomial time, then d-DNNFnFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFnFBDD being no-poly-quasi \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bova_2016}.

quasiDescription.description: The quasi-polynomial compilation from $dec$-$DNNF$ to $FBDD$ yields a $uFBDD$ when applied to a $d$-$DNNF$.

matrix.description:
First, we show no polynomial transformation exists.
uFBDDnFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNFuFBDD in polynomial time, then d-DNNFnFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFnFBDD being no-poly-quasi \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bova_2016}.

Now, we show a quasipolynomial transformation exists.
The quasi-polynomial compilation from $dec$-$DNNF$ to $FBDD$ yields a $uFBDD$ when applied to a $d$-$DNNF$.
uFBDDd-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNFuOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then uFBDDuOBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts uFBDDuOBDD being no-quasi.

OBDDFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If d-DNNFOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNFFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFFBDD being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2000}.
Shown by Corollary 3.5 of \citet{Beame_2013}.

dec-SDNNFdec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-DNNFdec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNFdec-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-DNNFdec-DNNF being no-quasi \citet{Beame_2013}.

OBDD$_<$d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}. If d-SDNNFCNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts OBDD$_<$CNF being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.
As defined by \citet{Amarilli_2018}, a $d$-$SDNNF$ is simply a structured $d$-$DNNF$, so transformation is trivial.

OBDD$_<$d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}. If d-SDNNFDNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts OBDD$_<$DNF being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. SDNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from d-SDNNF to DNNF.

dec-SDNNFd-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. FBDDnFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-SDNNFFBDD in polynomial time, then dec-SDNNFnFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts dec-SDNNFnFBDD being no-poly-quasi \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bova_2016}.

IPDNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If d-SDNNFIP in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNFDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-SDNNFDNF being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

MODSCNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If d-SDNNFMODS in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNFCNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts d-SDNNFCNF being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

noPolyDescription.description: dec-SDNNFd-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-SDNNFnFBDD in polynomial time, then dec-SDNNFnFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts dec-SDNNFnFBDD being no-poly-quasi \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bova_2016}.

quasiDescription.description: d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. SDNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. DNNF transforms to nFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from d-SDNNF to nFBDD.

First, we show no polynomial transformation exists.
dec-SDNNFd-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If d-SDNNFnFBDD in polynomial time, then dec-SDNNFnFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts dec-SDNNFnFBDD being no-poly-quasi \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bova_2016}.

Now, we show a quasipolynomial transformation exists.
d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. SDNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. DNNF transforms to nFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from d-SDNNF to nFBDD.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. SDNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from d-SDNNF to NNF.

Unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses.

Explanation: Suppose not; then $\forall\Lambda\in DNF$, $\exists$ an equivalent $\Lambda_*\in d$-$DNNF$ of polynomial size. Then we may perform a clausal entailment check on some $CNF$ sentence $\Sigma \in CNF$ with respect to some clause $\gamma$ by checking whether $(\neg\Sigma\vee\gamma)\in DNF$ is valid. But we may perform a validity check on $(\neg\Sigma\vee\gamma)_* \in d$-$DNNF$ in polynomial time. Since we can now perform a polynomial-time clausal entailment check on all $CNF$ sentences, the polynomial hierarchy collapses.
d-SDNNFd-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If DNFd-SDNNF in polynomial time, then DNFd-DNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts DNFd-DNNF being no-poly-unknown-quasi.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $DNF$ is a subset of $DNNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.

Appendix D.2 of \citet{Pipatsrisawat_2010} and Section 6.3 of \citet{Capelli_2016} independently proved this result using different techniques.
As defined by "Connecting Knowledge Compilation Classes and Width Parameters", $FBDD$ is the subset of $uFBDD$ with no $\vee$-nodes

uOBDDd-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If FBDDuOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then FBDDd-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts FBDDd-SDNNF being no-quasi \citet{Amarilli_2018}.
The hidden weighted bit function has a lower-bounded $OBDD$ representation of $\Omega(2^{n/4})$, while an $FBDD$ for the same function has a size of only $O(n^2)$

Recursively rewire every internal node $n$ labeled with variable $x$ by a circuit $(x\wedge D_0)\vee (\neg x \wedge D_1)$, where $D_0$ and $D_1$ are the (not necessarily disjoint) rewirings of the nodes to which $n$ respectively had a 0-edge and a 1-edge. We note that the new $\vee$-gate is a decision gate and the two $\wedge$ gates are decomposable. Furthermore, $\vee$ gates are only introduced in the rewriting, so we obtain a $dec$-$DNNF$ in linear time.

dec-SDNNFOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015,Darwiche_2002}. If FBDDdec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then FBDDOBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts FBDDOBDD being no-quasi \citet{Gergov_1994}.

Consider the $DNF$ formula $\Pi_n= igvee_{i=0}^{n-1}(x_{2i} \wedge x_{2i+1})$. This formula is in prime implicants form and each clause in $\Pi_n$ is an essential prime implicant of it. Hence its negation $
eg\Pi_n\in IP$.

Since the early work of Quine, we know that the number of essential prime implicates of a formula is a lower bound on the number of clauses that can be found in any $CNF$ representation of it. However, since $\Pi_n$ has $2^n$ prime implicants, $
eg\Pi_n$ has $2^n$ prime implicates, so any $CNF$ representation of $
eg\Pi_n$ must have at least $2^n$ clauses.
This is listed as an open problem in the Knowledge Compilation Map (2002).
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $IP$ is a subset of $DNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.
IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. DNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from IP to DNNF.

Define the interpretation $I\in\{0,1\}^{n^2}$, as arcs on a directed graph $D=\{V,E\}$ with $n$ vertices so that $I(x_{i,j})=1\iff (i,j)\in E$. Then define $
eg\Sigma_{n,k}:\{0,1\}^{n^2}	o\{0,1\}$ so $
eg\Sigma_{n,k}(I)=0 \iff I 	ext{ contains a bidirectional clique of size }k$. It can be shown that for certain values of $k$ (dependent on $n$), every $FBDD$ representation of $
eg\Sigma_{n,k}$ has exponential size. This is the negation of the clique detection function. However, it can be shown that $
eg\Sigma_{n,k}$ has $O(n^3)$ prime implicates, which implies that not every $IP$ formula cannot be converted to $FBDD$ in quasi-polynomial-time.
The function $ANY_n=\bigvee_{i=1}^nx_i$ can be represented in $O(n)$ as a $IP$ formula but has $2^n-1$ models.

IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. DNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. DNNF transforms to nFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from IP to nFBDD.

IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. DNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from IP to NNF.

OBDD$_<$FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If IPOBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then IPFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts IPFBDD being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002,Wegener_1987}.
PICNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If IPPI in quasipolynomial time, then IPCNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts IPCNF being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

dec-SDNNFFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If IPdec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then IPFBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts IPFBDD being no-quasi \citet{Darwiche_2002,Wegener_1987}.

A Shannon tree for any for any $MODS$ formula can be generated in polynomial time. The set of all paths from the root of the tree to any 0-leaf can be read as a $CNF$ representation of the formula, so $MODS$ is converted to $CNF$.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $MODS$ is a subset of $d-DNNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.

MODS transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to d-SDNNF.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $MODS$ is a subset of $DNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.

MODS transforms to OBDD$_<$ in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. FBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. nFBDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to DNNF.

MODS transforms to OBDD$_<$ in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to FBDD.
The Quine-McCluskey algorithm generates an $IP$ formula in polynomial time.

MODS transforms to OBDD$_<$ in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. FBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to nFBDD.

MODS transforms to OBDD$_<$ in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. FBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. nFBDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to NNF.

MODS transforms to OBDD$_<$ in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to uOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uOBDD transforms to nOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to nOBDD.
A Shannon tree for any for any $MODS$ formula following any order $<$ can be generated in polynomial time. This tree can be reduced into a corresponding $OBDD_<$ in polynomial time.

The transformation is in fact linear. We may recursively rewire every internal node $n$ labeled with variable $x$ by a circuit $(x\wedge D_0)\vee(\neg x \wedge D_1)$, where $D_0$ and $D_1$ are the rewiring of nodes to which $n$ respectively had a 0-edge and 1-edge. Note that the new $\vee$-gate is a decision gate and the two $\wedge$-gates are decomposable, so we attain a $DNNF$.

Consider the Boolean functions $\psi_n,\phi_n:\{0,1\}^{n^2}\to\{0,1\}$ that respectively test whether, in an $n \times n$ Boolean matrix, either the number of 1's is odd and there is a full row of 1's, or the number of 1's is even and there is a column full of 1's. An $FBDD$ of size $O(n^2)$ may simulate either $\psi_n$ or $\phi_n$, and thus the $uFBDD$ $\psi_n\vee\phi_n$ is of size $O(n^2)$; however, an $FBDD$ for $\psi_n\vee\phi_n$ is provably of size $2^{\Omega(n^{1/2})}$.

From the variable order $v$, construct a right-linear $v$-tree $T$ as follows: let $r_1$ be the root; for $2 \le i \le n-1$, let $r_i$ be the left child of $r_{i-1}$; for $1 \le i \le n-1$, attach leaf $v_i$ as the right child of $r_i$, and attach leaf $v_n$ as the right child of $r_{n-1}$.
Next, apply the standard compilation of an $n$-FBDD into a DNNF by rewriting each decision node labeled by variable $x$ as $(x \wedge D_0) \vee (\neg x \wedge D_1)$, where $D_0$ and $D_1$ are the rewritings of the respective successors. Because the $v$-tree aligns with the variable order of the $n$-OBDD, every $\wedge$-gate respects the variable partition induced by $T$, yielding a structured DNNF. The construction is linear in the size of $D$.

Consider the $CNF$ formula $\Sigma_n= igwedge_{i=0}^{n-1}(x_{2i} \vee x_{2i+1})$. This formula is in prime implicates form and each clause in $\Sigma_n$ is an essential prime implicate of it. Hence its negation $
eg\Sigma_n\in PI$.

Since the work of Quine, we know that the number of essential prime implicants of a formula is a lower bound on the number of terms that can be found in any $DNF$ representation of it. However, since $\Sigma_n$ has $2^n$ prime implicates, $
eg\Sigma_n$ has $2^n$ prime implicants, so any $DNF$ representation of $
eg\Sigma_n$ must have at least $2^n$ clauses.
This is listed as an open problem in the Knowledge Compilation Map (2002).

Define the interpretation $I\in\{0,1\}^{n^2}$, as arcs on a directed graph $D=\{V,E\}$ with $n$ vertices so that $I(x_{i,j})=1\iff (i,j)\in E$. Then define $\Sigma_{n,k}:\{0,1\}^{n^2}\to\{0,1\}$ so $\Sigma_{n,k}(I)=1 \iff I \text{ contains a bidirectional clique of size }k$. This is the clique detection function. It can be shown that for certain values of $k$ (dependent on $n$), every $FBDD$ representation of $\Sigma_{n,k}$ has exponential size. However, it can be shown that $\Sigma_{n,k}$ has $O(n^3)$ prime implicants, and hence not every $PI$ formula cannot be converted to $FBDD$ in quasi-polynomial-time.

The transformation is in fact linear. We may recursively rewire every internal node $n$ labeled with variable $x$ by a circuit $(x\wedge D_0)\vee(\neg x \wedge D_1)$, where $D_0$ and $D_1$ are the rewiring of nodes to which $n$ respectively had a 0-edge and 1-edge. Note that the new $\vee$-gate is a decision gate and the two $\wedge$-gates are decomposable; furthermore, all $\vee$-gates in the rewiring are deterministic, so we attain a $d$-$DNNF$.

Consider the Boolean functions $\phi_n, \psi_n: \{0,1\}^{n^2}\to\{0,1\}$, which respectively test whether, in an $n\times n$ Boolean matrix, that the number of 1's is odd and there is a row full of 1's, and that the number of 1's is even and there is a column full of 1's. \citet{Bova_2016} and \citet{Wegener_2000} show that an $FBDD$ expression for $\phi_n \vee \psi_n$ has necessarily size $2^{\Omega(n^{1/2})}$; but since an $FBDD$ of size $O(n^2)$ may test $\phi_n$ or $\psi_n$ separately (shown by Proposition 3.1 of \citet{Amarilli_2018}), a $uFBDD$ for $\phi_n\vee \psi_n$ may be obtained by simply adding an $\vee$-gate joining these two $FBDD$ expressions, since $\phi_n \wedge \psi_n$ is unsatisfiable.

From the variable order $v$, construct a right-linear $v$-tree $T$ as follows: let $r_1$ be the root; for $2 \le i \le n-1$, let $r_i$ be the left child of $r_{i-1}$; for $1 \le i \le n-1$, attach leaf $v_i$ as the right child of $r_i$, and attach leaf $v_n$ as the right child of $r_{n-1}$.
Next, apply the standard compilation of an $n$-FBDD into a DNNF by rewriting each decision node labeled by variable $x$ as $(x \wedge D_0) \vee (\neg x \wedge D_1)$, where $D_0$ and $D_1$ are the rewritings of the respective successors. Because the $v$-tree aligns with the variable order of the $n$-OBDD, every $\wedge$-gate respects the variable partition induced by $T$, yielding a structured DNNF. The construction is linear in the size of $D$. Since $D$ is unambiguous, for every rewritten node the two subcircuits $(x \wedge D_0)$ and $(\neg x \wedge D_1)$ are mutually exclusive, ensuring that all $\vee$-gates introduced in the translation are deterministic. The resulting circuit is therefore a deterministic structured DNNF (d-SDNNF), and the compilation remains linear-time.

From the variable order $v$, construct a right-linear $v$-tree $T$ as follows: let $r_1$ be the root; for $2 \le i \le n-1$, let $r_i$ be the left child of $r_{i-1}$; for $1 \le i \le n-1$, attach leaf $v_i$ as the right child of $r_i$, and attach leaf $v_n$ as the right child of $r_{n-1}$.
Next, apply the standard compilation of an $n$-FBDD into a DNNF by rewriting each decision node labeled by variable $x$ as $(x \wedge D_0) \vee (\neg x \wedge D_1)$, where $D_0$ and $D_1$ are the rewritings of the respective successors. Because the $v$-tree aligns with the variable order of the $n$-OBDD, every $\wedge$-gate respects the variable partition induced by $T$, yielding a structured DNNF. The construction is linear in the size of $D$. Since $D$ is unambiguous, for every rewritten node the two subcircuits $(x \wedge D_0)$ and $(\neg x \wedge D_1)$ are mutually exclusive, ensuring that all $\vee$-gates introduced in the translation are deterministic. The resulting circuit is therefore a deterministic structured DNNF (d-SDNNF), and the compilation remains linear-time.  In the case of an OBDD, all disjunctions in the resulting circuit arise from the rewriting of decision nodes, so every $\vee$-gate is a decision gate. Combined with the structured decomposability ensured by the $v$-tree, this yields a dec-SDNNF. The translation is linear in the size of $D$.

quasiDescription.description: Theorem 2 of \citet{Bollig_2018} shows that $SDNNF$ can be compiled into $nOBDD$ by adapting the compilation of \citet{Beame_2015} from $DNNF$ to $nFBDD$; proposition 2 of \citet{Bollig_2018} shows that this $nOBDD$ is unambiguous if the $SDNNF$ is deterministic. Additionally, the same compilation yields an $OBDD$ if the input is a $dec$-$SDNNF$ since there are no $\vee$-gates that are not decision gates in a $dec$-$SDNNF$.

matrix.description:
First, we show no polynomial transformation exists.
OBDDFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If dec-SDNNFOBDD in polynomial time, then dec-SDNNFFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts dec-SDNNFFBDD being no-poly-quasi \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}.

Now, we show a quasipolynomial transformation exists.
Theorem 2 of \citet{Bollig_2018} shows that $SDNNF$ can be compiled into $nOBDD$ by adapting the compilation of \citet{Beame_2015} from $DNNF$ to $nFBDD$; proposition 2 of \citet{Bollig_2018} shows that this $nOBDD$ is unambiguous if the $SDNNF$ is deterministic. Additionally, the same compilation yields an $OBDD$ if the input is a $dec$-$SDNNF$ since there are no $\vee$-gates that are not decision gates in a $dec$-$SDNNF$.
As defined by \citet{Amarilli_2018}, a $dec$-$SDNNF$ is simply a structured $dec$-$DNNF$, so discarding the v-tree completes the transformation.

separatingFunctions.name: $\Sigma_n = \bigwedge_{i=0}^{n-1} \left( x_{2i} \vee x_{2i+1} \right)$
separatingFunctions.description: This formula describes evaluating where given each pair $x_{2i}$ and $x_{2i+1}$, at least one of must be true. It is the dual to the Pairwise DNF.

separatingFunctions.name: $\Pi_n = \bigvee_{i=0}^{n-1} \left( x_{2i} \wedge x_{2i+1} \right)$
separatingFunctions.description: This formula describes evaluating where after pairing $x_{2i}$ and $x_{2i+1}$, at least one pair must have both be true. It is the dual to the Pairwise CNF.

separatingFunctions.name: Parity function
separatingFunctions.description: $O_n = \bigoplus_{i=0}^{n-1} x_i$ has linear size $OBBD_<$ representations but exponential size CNF and DNF representations.

separatingFunctions.name: $OR_n = \bigvee_{i=1}^{n} x_i$
separatingFunctions.description: Separates languages that compactly represent disjunctions from those that cannot.

separatingFunctions.name: Clique Detection Instances
separatingFunctions.description: Define the interpretation $I\in\{0,1\}^{n^2}$, as arcs on a directed graph $D=\{V,E\}$ with $n$ vertices so that $I(x_{i,j})=1\iff (i,j)\in E$. Then define $\Sigma_{n,k}:\{0,1\}^{n^2}\to\{0,1\}$ so $\Sigma_{n,k}(I)=1 \iff I \text{ contains a bidirectional clique of size }k$.
